column9: Origin
Fabia Aconia Paulina; Roman aristocratic woman, wife of Praetextatus (d. c. 384).
Aelia Oculata; Roman vestal virgin (c. 83).
Cornelia Africana; Roman noblewoman, wife of Tiberus Gracchus Major, mother of Tiberus and Gaius Gracchus (c. 190-100 B.C.).
Roman festival celebrated several times a year; on this day the Rex sacrorum offered a ram in the Regia.
Alba Longa (usually identified with Castel Gandolfo), in the Alban Hills, 25 km SE of Rome. Ancient city founded by Ascanius.
Roman vestal virgin.
Albia Dominica; Roman noblewoman, wife of Emperor Valens (c. 337–378).
Roman noblewoman, daughter of Anthemius and Aelia Euphemia, wife of Ricimer (fl. 467-472).
Angioletta Coradini; Italian planetary scientist (1946-2011).
Famous Roman woman, daughter of M. Antonius and Octavia, wife of Drusus, mother of Germanicus, Livilla, and Emperor Claudius (36 B.C. - A.D. 37).
Julia Aquilia Severa; Roman vestal virgin (c. 218).
City at the foot of Albanus Mons, once a powerful city in early Latium (present-day Ariccia).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 70 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 3rd century).
Roman festival of Bacchus celebrated on the day of the winter solstice.
Bruttia Crispina; Roman Empress, wife of Emperor Commodus (164-191).
Atia Balba Caesonia; Roman noblewoman, daughter of Julius Ceasar’s sister, mother of Emperor Augustus (85-43 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 3rd century).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 213).
One of the first Roman vestal virgins.
Roman vestal virgin (d. 266 B.C.).
Roman Empress, daughter of military commander Lucillianus, wife of Emperor Jovian (mid 4th century C.E.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 143 B.C.).
Coelia Concordia; the last Roman vestal virgin and the last Vestalis Maxima (Chief Vestal) after the Temple of Vesta was closed in 391 (d. 406 A.D.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 23).
Roman vestal virgin.
Roman festival held on December 21 in honor of the goddess Angerona.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 10-19).
Julia; wife of Roman emperor Severus.
Julia; famous Roman woman, second daughter of Germanicus and Agrippina, sister of Gaius (16-38).
Priestess and prominent citizen of Pompeii (c. 1st century).
Famous Roman woman, second wife of Constantius II.
Wife of Maximian (c. 324).
Roman vestal virgin (served as a vestal virgin from 73 to pre 58 B.C.).
Flavia Maxima; Roman Empress, wife of Constantine I, executed by him (d. 326).
Roman All Souls’ Day (February 21) where each household made offerings at the graves of its dead.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 215).
Roman vestal virgin (d. 216 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 69 B.C.).
Wife of Clodius, Curio, and Antony.
Annia Fundania Faustina; Roman noblewoman, cousin of M. Aurelius, victim of Commodus (d. 192).
Galeria Fundana; wife of Emperor Vitellius, (c. 1st century).
Roman vestal virgin.
Pomponia Graecina; Roman noblewoman, married to the consul Aulus Plautius (d. A.D. 83).
Flavia Iulia Helena Augusta; mother of Constantine the Great.
Herennia Etruscilla; Roman Empress, wife of Emperor Decius, mother of Emperors Etruscus Herrenius and Hostilian (c. 250).
Daughter of consul and advocate Quintus Hortensius (fl. c. 50 B.C.); she was known as a skilled orator.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 107).
Famous Roman woman, second wife of Emperor Valentinian.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 62).
Clodia; Roman vestal virgin (c. 213).
Acca; mythical woman, wife of the shepherd Faustulus in Roman mythology, adoptive mother of Romulus and Remus.
Roman city revered it for its Aeneas traditions, its Venus temple, and it cults of Vesta (now Pratica de Mare).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 25).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 140-113 B.C.).
Lollia Paulina; Roman woman of distinguished ancestry and great wealth, Roman Empress as the third wife of Caligula (15-49).
Domitia; Roman empress, wife of Emperor Domitian, Augusta of Rome (c. 51-130).
Ancient Roman feast held on July 19 when the Romans, defeated and pursued by the Gauls, retired and concealed themselves in the woods.
Annia; Roman Empress, mother of M. Aurelius, married to Emperors L. Verus, and then to Ti. Claudius (c. 150-182).
Roman festival reflecting the needs of a small pastoral community, involving the sacrifice of goats and youths striking those whom they met with strips of goat skins, held February 15.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 240).
Roman vestal virgin (d. 113 B.C.).
Second wife of Herod, king of Roman province Judea, known for her great beauty (c. 60-29 B.C.).
Roman festival associated with the goddess Juno, celebrated on March 1.
Claudia Metrodora; Greek woman with Roman citizenship, prominent public benefactor (mid 1st century A.D.).
The first wife of the Roman Emperor Constantine the Great, mother of Crispus (early 4th century).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 337 B.C.).
Daughter of Pythagoras and Theano, wife of Milon of Crotona.
Roman festival held on July 23 in the heat of the summer to honor Neptunus, god of water.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 204).
Roman vestal virgin (served as vestal virgin from c. 40 B.C. to A.D. 19).
Roman vestal virgin (third century A.D.).
Roman vestal virgin (d. 483 B.C.).
Paculla Annia; Campanian (Southern Italy) priestess of Bacchus whose reforms radically altered the Bacchanalian ritual in ancient Rome (fl. c. 188 B.C.).
Roman festival that included performance of funeral rites, at the first day of the nine-day Parentalia festival honoring ancestors.
Roman festival of the shepherds' and livestocks' god and goddess Pales, held on April 21, feast of purification of the beast, herdsmen, and stalls.
Aurelia; priestess for life of asylum-granting Artemis Pergaia, built hydreion at her own expense.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 100-70 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 600 B.C.).
Galla; daughter of the Roman Emperor Theodorius I, wife of Athualf, King of the Visigoths, and Constantius III, Roman Emperor (390-450).
Plancia Magna; daughter of Roman Senator Varus, wife of Tertullus, benefactress and patron of Perga, the capital of the Roman province of Pamphylia in Asia Minor (1st-2nd century A.D.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 213).
Daughter of Roman statesman Cato Uticensis, second wife of M. Brutus (c. 70-43/42 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 420 B.C.).
Flavia Publicia; Roman vestal virgin (c. 213).
Rhea Silvia, Roman vestal virgin, mother of Romulus and Remus (c. 770 B.C.).
Roman festival where a dog was sacrificed to the god Robigus to prevent the red dust, or mildew, which attacked corn when the ear was beginning to form.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 54).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 250-301).
Three-day Roman festival starting on December 17, with sacrifices, public feasting, gifts, and slaves were waited on by their masters.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 40 B.C.-A.D. 23).
Amaesia Sentia; mentioned by Valerius Maximus as an instance of a female who pleaded her own cause before the praetor; called “Androgyne” for having a man’s spirit with a female body.
Roman noblewoman, niece of Emperor Theodosius (c. 400).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 240).
Roman vestal virgin (d. 274 B.C.).
Roman vestal virgin.
Roman vestal virgin.
Teia Euphrosyne Ruffina, Roman vestal virgin (c. 200).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 48).
Roman vestal virgin.
Roman vestal virgin.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 10-83).
One of the first Roman vestal virgins.
Roman festival of Vesta, held June 7-15.
Roman vestal virgin (c. 200).
Roman vestal virgin (c. 48).
